entry.title: Stevie Ray Vaughan: 27 Years Gone
entry.content:
August 27, 1990 was a tragic day for the world of music; the day that Stevie Ray Vaughan boarded a helicopter that would never make it out of Alpine Valley in East Troy, WI. The helicopter crashed into a hill in dense fog around midnight following a concert. SRV, 3 of Eric Clapton's entourage, and the pilot, were all killed. I can only wonder and imagine what Stevie would be up to these days if he were still around.

I didn't know who Stevie was until I was around 20 years old, but he changed everything for me. Here's a little of the story about how I discovered him, as I told it on Instagram last year on what would have been his 62nd birthday.

"The first time that I heard one of Stevie's songs was while I was working at Chili's, circa 1997. "Pride and Joy" was one of the songs on one of our compilation CD's that played throughout the restaurant. I still remember right where I was, bussing a table, when it came on. I had never listened to the blues or anything directly influenced by it before. I was very much into 90's rock at the time. But that song changed everything; I was hooked. Thank you, Stevie, for opening up my world."

I'll definitely be listening to some Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble in honor of SRV. If you haven't discovered his music yet, I highly recommend that you do so immediately. 

P.S. I couldn't find the actual video footage of the video above, but it's really worth a watch. It's "Leave My Little Girl Alone" from the 1989 Austin City Limits show. Enjoy!

entry.title: The Personal Guitar Workshop
entry.content:
Now this is an invention that I can get behind. Even when I was playing guitar every day, all day (back when I was young and single), I probably only changed my strings like once every six months. I know, I know. But no matter how often you change them, it's a pain in the ass. You have to try to hold your guitar between your legs and position it just right. Maybe lay it on your lap and try not to drop it on the ground while pushing in the bridge pins on your acoustic. There has to be a better way, right? Well, now there is! Or at least there could be...

Enter the Personal Guitar Workshop; a new Kickstarter campaign by founder/inventor Dave Sommerfield. The idea was to create "a device that would make caring for our beloved instruments easier." I believe that it will do just that.

The awesome part is that it doesn't matter if you play acoustic or electric guitar, it will work for both. It also doubles (or triples?) as a guitar stand! Pretty sweet if you ask me. If you're feeling inspired and generous go check out the project and become a supporter.

entry.title: Steve Vai on Allan Holdsworth
entry.content:
Steve Vai and I don't have a whole lot in common. He's a way better guitarist then me and he has a much cooler look then me. The one thing that we do have in common, though, is that we have a hard time calling anyone the greatest guitarist of all time.

Stevie Ray Vaughan is definitely my favorite, but I wouldn't be so bold as to call him the best of all time. While Steve Vai was listing out some of the greats in his interview with Music Radar, he did propose that Allan Holdsworth could possibly hold that coveted title in his mind. Here's what he had to say:

"I very rarely agree with the term best guitar player. It just seems so obscene to put something so subjective into a best category.

"But if I had to say there was one, I would pick Allan Holdsworth.

"He was unique in ways that I don't think have been discovered yet. Many musicians can be considered ahead of their time, but usually - they're not. They're mainly ahead of everyone else at that time.

"For example, Jimi Hendrix wasn't ahead of his time; he was perfect for his time and ahead of everyone else.

"Allan Holdsworth was definitely ahead of his time because it's hard to realize how great he is - not many people actually understand. It takes time for us to catch up with those that are ahead of their time.

"I would not be surprised if in 100 years from now, if people are still even listening to guitar - which I suspect they will be - he'll be singled out as 'the one' alone, so to speak.

"The way he uses the whole tone scale is like his own baby shoes - it's so easy for him. His thought process was phenomenal.

"I can hear any guitar player and I know what they're doing - I might not be able to play it - but I can see it in my mind's eye.

"But I do not know what the fuck Holdsworth was doing at all..."

I honestly had never heard of Holdsworth, but you can bet that I looked him up immediately. I don't really even know how to describe what I found. It's this sort of jazz fusion madness and there's something in his playing that I can't explain; it's mesmerizing and a bit confusing. The guy is all over the fretboard, manipulating notes that I had no idea even belonged together. I don't know if he's the greatest guitarist of all time, but he's got to be up there.

Sadly, in my research I also found that he passed away not long ago on April 15, 2017. Have a listen and help keep Allan Holdsworth's music alive.
